ETYMOLOGY: From Middle French 'sentiment', from Old French 'sentement' ('feeling, opinion'), from Latin 'sentīmentum' ('feeling, sensation'), from 'sentīre' ('to feel').

MEANINGS.PATTERN:
public sentiment
express sentiment | a sentiment
MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun). Can be countable or uncountable.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A general feeling, attitude, or opinion, especially one held by a group of people.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （尤指集体持有的）情感，情绪；看法，观点。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Public sentiment is largely against the proposed tax increase.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 公众对提议的增税方案普遍持反对意见。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun). Can be countable or uncountable.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A tender, romantic, or nostalgic feeling or emotion.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He expressed his personal sentiments on the matter with great sincerity.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他真诚地表达了自己对此事的个人情感。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun). Can be countable or uncountable.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Excessive tenderness, sadness, or nostalgia; sentimentality.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: His novel was criticized for being overwrought and full of idle sentiment.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他的小说因过于煽情和充满无谓的滥情而受到批评。
